(Critical)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/git.rs] [Function: clone()] [Command Injection] Does the clone() function properly sanitize the target_path parameter to prevent injection of additional git arguments or commands through special characters like '--config', '--upload-pack', or newlines that could modify git behavior? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/git.rs] [Function: checkout()] [Command Injection] Can an attacker exploit the 'rev' parameter in checkout() by providing malicious strings like '$(malicious_command)' or '`command`' to execute arbitrary commands when checking out a specific revision? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/git.rs] [Function: checkout()] [Argument Injection] Can the 'rev' parameter be manipulated to include git options like '--exec=malicious_script' or '-c core.sshCommand=...' that alter git's execution behavior and potentially lead to remote code execution? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/git.rs] [Function: reset_hard()] [Command Injection] Does reset_hard() validate the 'rev' parameter before constructing 'origin/{rev}', or can attackers inject commands through specially crafted branch names containing shell metacharacters? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/git.rs] [Function: find_rev()] [Command Injection] Can the 'rev' parameter in find_rev() be exploited with git argument injection (e.g., '--exec', '-c', or special refs like 'refs/pull/*/head') to execute arbitrary code during revision verification? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/git.rs] [Function: find_tag()] [Command Injection] Is the 'rev' parameter in find_tag() properly sanitized to prevent injection of git arguments or special patterns that could list unauthorized tags or execute commands? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/git.rs] [Function: clone()] [Path Traversal] Can an attacker provide a target_path containing '../' sequences or absolute paths to write the cloned repository outside the intended directory, potentially overwriting critical system files or Move framework code? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/git.rs] [Function: clone()] [Path Traversal] Does clone() validate that target_path doesn't contain symbolic links that could be exploited to redirect the repository clone to arbitrary filesystem locations, enabling unauthorized file overwrites? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/git.rs] [Function: checkout()] [Path Traversal] Can the repo_path parameter in checkout() be manipulated with path traversal sequences to execute git operations on repositories outside the intended dependency directory structure? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/git.rs] [Function: fetch_origin()] [Path Traversal] Is repo_path in fetch_origin() validated to prevent operations on system git repositories (e.g., '/etc/git', '/usr/local/git') that could compromise the host system? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/git.rs] [Function: reset_hard()] [Path Traversal] Does reset_hard() verify that repo_path points to a valid, sandboxed location before executing 'git reset --hard', preventing destructive operations on unintended repositories? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/git.rs] [Function: clone()] [Protocol Confusion] Can an attacker specify malicious git URLs using dangerous protocols (e.g., 'ext::', 'fd::', 'file://' with privileged paths) that bypass security restrictions and access local filesystem or execute commands? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/git.rs] [Function: clone()] [URL Injection] Does clone() validate that the URL points to an authorized git repository host, or can attackers clone from internal/private repositories by providing URLs like 'http://localhost:8080/internal-repo.git'? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/git.rs] [Function: clone()] [Git Submodule Attack] If the cloned repository contains malicious git submodules with dangerous URLs or hooks, can they be exploited to execute arbitrary code during the clone operation despite stdout/stderr being redirected to null? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/git.rs] [Function: clone()] [Git Hooks Exploitation] Does the cloned repository's git hooks (pre-commit, post-checkout, etc.) get executed during subsequent git operations, allowing malicious package authors to execute arbitrary code on developer/validator machines? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/git.rs] [Function: clone()] [SSH Key Abuse] Can attackers exploit git's SSH protocol handling by crafting URLs with embedded SSH options (e.g., 'ssh://-oProxyCommand=malicious@host/repo.git') to execute commands during clone? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/git.rs] [Function: clone()] [TOCTOU Race Condition] Is there a race condition between checking if target_path exists and cloning the repository, allowing an attacker to create a symlink at that path after the check but before the clone, redirecting the operation? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/git.rs] [Function: checkout()] [Race Condition] Can concurrent checkout() operations on the same repo_path from multiple threads cause race conditions that result in inconsistent repository state or partially checked out malicious code? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/git.rs] [Function: fetch_origin()] [Race Condition] If multiple processes simultaneously call fetch_origin() on the same repository, can race conditions in git's object database corruption or lock contention lead to corrupted dependency resolution? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/git.rs] [Function: reset_hard()] [TOCTOU Vulnerability] Is there a time-of-check-time-of-use vulnerability where repo_path is validated but then modified (via symlink swap) before reset_hard executes, allowing destructive operations on unintended repositories? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/git.rs] [Function: clone()] [Dependency Confusion] Can an attacker perform dependency confusion attacks by registering similar package names and tricking clone() to fetch from a malicious repository URL instead of the legitimate one? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/git.rs] [Function: checkout()] [Ref Confusion] Does checkout() properly distinguish between tags, branches, and commit hashes, or can an attacker create a malicious tag with the same name as a legitimate branch to serve different code? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/git.rs] [Function: find_tag()] [Tag Spoofing] Can an attacker create multiple tags with the same name or similar names (e.g., using Unicode homoglyphs) to confuse package resolution and inject malicious code versions? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/git.rs] [Function: find_rev()] [Commit Hash Collision] If find_rev() accepts abbreviated commit hashes, can an attacker exploit hash collisions to make the system checkout a malicious commit with a similar short hash? (Medium)
